case_vignette: A 3-week-old healthy female is brought to dermatology clinic for evaluation of spots on the face. Patient's mother noted the spots developed about one week ago on the cheeks and then spread to the forehead. She has not tried any treatments and has not used any new bathing or topical products. Examination reveals multiple scattered inflammatory papules and few scatteres pustules on erythematous bases on the forehead, cheeks and nasal bridge. External genitalia are normal. KOH from the pustule does not reveal any fungal or microrganisms.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have spots on my face that look red and some have little bumps with pus.
Have you noticed any itching or burning sensation around these spots?
No, there's no itching or burning.
Have you had any recent changes in your diet or lifestyle?
No, there haven't been any changes in my diet or lifestyle.
Have you had any recent travel history?
No, I haven't traveled recently.
Have you had any recent skin injuries or trauma?
No, I haven't had any skin injuries or trauma.
Have you had any family history of skin conditions?
The vignette doesn't mention anything about a family history of skin conditions.
Final Diagnosis: Acne.
